{{short description|The use of language of goal-directedness in the context of evolutionary adaptation}} {{good article}} [[File:Springbok pronk.jpg|thumb|"Behaviour with a purpose": a young [[springbok]] [[stotting]].<ref name=Stanford/><ref name=Caro>{{cite journal | url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0003347286800525 | title=The functions of stotting in Thomson’s gazelles: Some tests of the predictions | author=Caro, TM |authorlink=Tim Caro | journal=Animal Behaviour | year=1986 | volume=34 | pages=663–684 | doi=10.1016/S0003-3472(86)80052-5}}</ref> A biologist might argue that this has the [[function (biology)|function]] of [[signalling theory|signalling to predators]], helping the springbok to survive and allowing it to reproduce.<ref name=Stanford/>]]
'''Teleology in biology''' is the use of the language of goal-directedness in accounts of [[evolution]]ary [[adaptation]], which some [[biology|biologists]] and [[philosophy of science|philosophers of science]] find problematic. The term [[teleonomy]] has also been proposed. Before [[Charles Darwin|Darwin]], organisms were seen as existing because God had [[creationism|designed and created]] them; their features such as eyes were taken by [[natural theology]] to have been made to enable them to carry out their [[function (biology)|functions]], such as seeing. [[Evolutionary biology|Evolutionary biologists]] often use similar teleological formulations that invoke purpose, but these imply [[natural selection]] rather than actual goals, whether conscious or not. Dissenting biologists and religious thinkers held that evolution itself was somehow goal-directed ([[orthogenesis]]), and in [[Vitalism|vitalist]] versions, driven by a purposeful life force. Since such views are now discredited, with evolution working by [[natural selection]] acting on inherited variation, the use of teleology in biology has attracted criticism, and attempts have been made to teach students to avoid teleological language.
Nevertheless, biologists still often write about evolution as if organisms had goals, and some [[philosophy of biology|philosophers of biology]] such as [[Francisco J. Ayala|Francisco Ayala]] and biologists such as [[J. B. S. Haldane]] consider that teleological language is unavoidable in [[evolutionary biology]].
==Context== ===Teleology=== {{main|Teleology}}
[[Teleology]], from [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] [[wikt:τέλος|τέλος]], ''telos'' "end, purpose"<ref>Eric Partridge, [https://books.google.com/books?id=xA9dxrhfa5kC&dq= ''Origins: A Short Etymological Dictionary of Modern English''], Routledge, 1977, p. 4187.</ref> and [[wikt:-λογία|-λογία]], ''logia'', "a branch of learning", was coined by the philosopher [[Christian von Wolff]] in 1728.<ref>{{cite book |author=Wolff, Christian von |author-link1=Christian Wolff (philosopher)| date=1732 | title=Philosophia Rationalis Sive Logica: Methodo Scientifica Pertractata Et Ad Usum Scientiarum Atque Vitae Aptata |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uQg_AAAAcAAJ}}</ref> The concept derives from the ancient Greek philosophy of [[Aristotle]], where the [[final cause]] (the purpose) of a thing is its [[function (biology)|function]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Presuppositions of Aristotle's Politics |url=http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/aristotle-politics/supplement2.html |publisher=Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy |accessdate=28 July 2016}}</ref> However, [[Aristotle's biology]] does not envisage [[evolution]] by [[natural selection]].<ref>{{cite book |author=Leroi, Armand Marie |authorlink=Armand Marie Leroi |title=The Lagoon: How Aristotle Invented Science |titlelink=Aristotle's Lagoon |publisher=Bloomsbury |date=2014 |isbn=978-1-4088-3622-4 |pages=272–275}}</ref>
Phrases used by biologists like "a function of ... is to ..." or "is designed for" are teleological at least in language. The presence of real or apparent teleology in explanations of natural selection is a controversial aspect of the [[philosophy of biology]], not least for its echoes of natural theology.<ref name=Stanford/><ref name=Futuyma>{{cite book |author=Futuyma, Douglas J. |authorlink=Douglas J. Futuyma |title=Evolutionary Biology |date=1998 |publisher=Sinauer Associates |pages=341, 342 |isbn=978-0-87893-189-7}}</ref>
[[File:John Ray from NPG.jpg|thumb|upright|The English [[natural theology|natural theologian]] [[John Ray]], and later [[William Derham]], used teleological arguments to illustrate the glory of God from nature.<ref name=Armstrong2000/>]]
===Natural theology=== {{main|Natural theology}}
Before Darwin, [[natural theology]] both assumed the existence of God and used the appearance of function in nature to argue for the existence of God.<ref name=Ayala/><ref name=Rosen/> The English [[parson-naturalist]] [[John Ray]] stated that his intention was "to illustrate the glory of God in the knowledge of the works of nature or creation".<ref name=Armstrong2000>{{cite book | title=The English Parson-Naturalist | publisher=Gracewing | author=Armstrong, Patrick | year=2000 | page=46 | isbn=0-85244-516-4}}</ref> Natural theology presented forms of the [[teleological argument]] or argument from design, namely that organs functioned well for their apparent purpose, so they were well-designed, so they must have been designed by a benevolent creator. For example, the eye had the function of seeing, and contained features like the [[iris (eye)|iris]] and [[lens (eye)|lens]] that assisted with seeing; therefore, ran the argument, it had been designed for that purpose.<ref name=Ayala>{{cite journal |author=Ayala, Francisco J. |authorlink=Francisco J. Ayala |date=2006 |title=Review of 'The Blasphemy of Intelligent Design: Creationism's Trojan Horse. The Wedge of Intelligent Design' by Barbara Forrest; Paul R. Gross |journal=History and Philosophy of the Life Sciences |volume=28 |issue=3 |pages=409–421 |jstor=23334140}}</ref><ref name=Rosen>{{cite web |author=Rosen, Gideon |url=http://www.princeton.edu/~grosen/puc/phi203/design.html |title=The Argument from Design |publisher=[[Princeton University]] |accessdate=10 April 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Paley |first1=William |last2=Paxton |first2=James |title=Natural Theology: Or, Evidences of the Existence and Attributes of the Deity, Collected from the Appearances of Nature |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VURKAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA18 |year=1837 |publisher=Gould, Kendall, and Lincoln |pages=18–}}</ref>
===Goal-directed evolution=== {{main|Orthogenesis|Vitalism}}
Religious thinkers and biologists have repeatedly supposed that evolution was driven by some kind of life force, a philosophy known as [[vitalism]], and have often supposed that it had some kind of goal or direction (towards which the life force was striving, if they also believed in that), known as [[orthogenesis]] or evolutionary progress. Such goal-directedness implies a long-term teleological force; some supporters of orthogenesis considered it to be a spiritual force, while others held that it was purely biological. For example, the Russian [[embryologist]] [[Karl Ernst von Baer]] believed in a teleological force in nature,<ref>Barbieri, Marcello. (2013). ''Biosemiotics: Information, Codes and Signs in Living Systems''. Nova Science Publishers. p. 7. {{ISBN|978-1-60021-612-1}}</ref><ref>Jacobsen, Eric Paul. (2005). ''From Cosmology to Ecology: The Monist World-view in Germany from 1770 to 1930''. p. 100. Peter Lang. {{ISBN|978-0-8204-7231-7}}</ref> whereas the French [[Spiritualism (philosophy)|spiritualist philosopher]] [[Henri Bergson]] linked orthogenesis with [[vitalism]], arguing for a creative force in evolution known as ''[[élan vital]]'' in his book ''[[Creative Evolution (book)|Creative Evolution]]'' (1907).<ref>[[Peter J. Bowler|Bowler, Peter J]]. (1992). ''The Eclipse of Darwinism: Anti-Darwinian Evolution Theories in the Decades around 1900''. The Johns Hopkins University Press. pp. 116–117. {{ISBN|978-0-8018-4391-4}}</ref> The French [[biophysicist]] [[Pierre Lecomte du Noüy]] and the American botanist [[Edmund Ware Sinnott]] developed vitalist evolutionary philosophies known as ''[[telefinalism]]'' and ''[[telism]]'' respectively. Their views were heavily criticized as non-scientific;<ref name="Koch 1957">{{cite journal | last1 = Koch | first1 = Leo Francis | year = 1957 | title = Vitalistic-Mechanistic Controversy | url = | journal = [[The Scientific Monthly]] | volume = 85 | issue = 5| pages = 245–255 }}</ref> the [[palaeontologist]] [[George Gaylord Simpson]] argued that Du Noüy and Sinnott were promoting religious versions of evolution.<ref>Simpson, George Gaylord. (1964). ''Evolutionary Theology: The New Mysticism''. In ''This View of Life: The World of an Evolutionist''. Harcourt, Brace & World. pp. 213–233</ref> The [[Jesuit]] [[paleontologist]] [[Pierre Teilhard de Chardin]] argued that evolution was aiming for a supposed spiritual "[[Omega Point]]" in what he called "directed additivity".<ref name="Lane 1996">Lane, David H. (1996). ''The Phenomenon of Teilhard: Prophet for a New Age''. Mercer University Press. pp. 60–64. {{ISBN|0-86554-498-0}}</ref><ref>De Chardin, Pierre Teilhard. (2003, reprint edition). ''The Human Phenomenon''. Sussex Academic Press. p. 65. {{ISBN|1-902210-30-1}}</ref> With the emergence of the [[modern synthesis (20th century)|modern evolutionary synthesis]], in which the [[genetics|genetic]] mechanisms of evolution were discovered, the hypothesis of orthogenesis was largely abandoned by biologists,<ref>Levinton, Jeffrey S. (2001). ''Genetics, Paleontology, and Macroevolution''. Cambridge University Press. pp. 14–16. {{ISBN|0-521-80317-9}}</ref><ref>Montgomery, Georgina M; Largent, Mark A. (2015). ''A Companion to the History of American Science''. Wiley. p. 218. {{ISBN|978-1-4051-5625-7}} "With the integration of Mendelian genetics and population genetics into evolutionary theory in the 1930s a new generation of biologists applied mathematical techniques to investigate how changes in the frequency of genes in populations combined with natural selection could produce species change. This demonstrated that Darwinian natural selection was the primary mechanism for evolution and that other models of evolution, such as neo-Lamarckism and orthogenesis, were invalid."</ref> especially with [[Ronald Fisher]]'s argument in his 1930 book ''[[The Genetical Theory of Natural Selection]]''.<ref>[[The Structure of Evolutionary Theory]] by [[Stephen Jay Gould]], Chapter 7, section "Synthesis as Restriction"</ref>
===Natural selection=== {{main|Natural selection|Evolution}}
[[Natural selection]], introduced in 1859 as the central mechanism{{efn|Darwin also introduced a second mechanism, [[sexual selection]], to explain traits such as the colourful "tail" train of the [[peacock]].<ref>{{cite book |author=Darwin, Charles |authorlink=Charles Darwin |date=1859 |title=On the Origin of Species |edition=1st |page=89 |url=http://darwin-online.org.uk/content/frameset?viewtype=side&itemID=F373&pageseq=12}}</ref>}} of [[evolution]] by [[Charles Darwin]], is the differential survival and reproduction of individuals due to differences in [[phenotype]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Zimmer |first1=Carl |authorlink1=Carl Zimmer |last2=Emlen |first2=Douglas J. |authorlink2=Douglas Emlen |year=2013 |title=Evolution: Making Sense of Life |edition=1st |publisher=Roberts and Company Publishers |isbn=978-1-936221-17-2}}</ref> The mechanism directly implies evolution, a change in [[Heredity|heritable]] [[Phenotypic trait|traits]] of a [[population]] over time.<ref>{{cite book |title=Strickberger's Evolution |edition=4th |author1=Hall, Brian K. |author2=Hallgrímsson, Benedikt |publisher=Jones and Bartlett |date=2008 |pages=4–6 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jrDD3cyA09kC&pg=PA4|isbn=978-1-4496-4722-3 }}</ref>
===Adaptation=== [[File:Sinornithosaurus IVPP V12811.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2<!--aspect for low image-->|Feathers today serve the function of [[bird flight|flight]], but they were co-opted rather than [[adaptation|adapted]] for this task, having evolved for an earlier purpose in [[theropods]] like ''[[Sinornithosaurus|Sinornithosaurus millenii]]'', perhaps [[Thermal insulation|insulation]].]] {{main|Adaptation|Function (biology)}}
A trait which persists in a population is often assumed by biologists to have been selected for in the course of evolution, raising the question of how the trait achieves this. Biologists call any such mechanism the function of the trait, using phrases like "A [[Function (biology)|function]] of [[stotting]] by antelopes is to [[signalling theory|communicate to predators]] that they have been detected",<ref name=Stanford>{{cite web |title=Teleological Notions in Biology |url=http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/teleology-biology/ |website=Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy |accessdate=28 July 2016 |date=18 May 2003}}</ref> or "The [[primate]] [[hand]] is designed (by natural selection) for grasping."<ref>{{cite web|title=Primates - marmosets, monkeys, apes, lemurs, humans|url=http://www.nhptv.org/wild/primates.asp |publisher=NHPTV |accessdate=28 July 2016 |quote=The hands and feet of all primates, except for humans, are designed for grasping. Humans have hands designed for grasping, but not feet! Humans have opposable thumbs.}}</ref>
An [[adaptation]] is an observable structure or other feature of an organism (for example, an [[enzyme]]) generated by natural selection to serve its current function. A biologist might propose the [[hypothesis]] that [[feather]]s are adaptations for [[bird flight]]. That would require three things: that the trait of having feathers is heritable; that the trait does serve the function of flight; and that the trait increases the [[fitness (biology)|fitness]] of the organisms that have it. Feathers clearly meet these three conditions in living [[birds]]. However, there is also a historical question, namely, did the trait arise at the same time as bird flight? Unfortunately for the hypothesis, this seems not to be so: [[theropod]] [[feathered dinosaur|dinosaurs had feathers]], but many of them did not fly.<ref name=Berkeley>{{cite web |title=Understanding Evolution: Qualifying as an adaptation |url=http://evolution.berkeley.edu/evolibrary/article/side_0_0/qualifying_01 |publisher=University of California at Berkeley |accessdate=29 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author1=Brusatte, Stephen L.|author2=Lloyd, Graeme T.|author3=Wang, Steve C.|author4=Norell, Mark A. |year=2014 |title=Gradual assembly of avian body plan culminated in rapid rates of evolution across the dinosaur-bird transition |journal=Current Biology |volume=24 |issue=20 |pages=2386–2392 |doi=10.1016/j.cub.2014.08.034 |pmid=25264248}}</ref> Feathers can be described as an [[exaptation]], having been co-opted for flight but having evolved earlier for another purpose such as [[Thermal insulation|insulation]]. Biologists may describe both the co-option and the earlier adaptation in teleological language.<ref name=Berkeley/><ref>{{Cite journal |date=4 April 2012 |author=Whitfield, John |title=Largest feathered dinosaur yet discovered in China |journal=Nature News Blog |url=http://blogs.nature.com/news/2012/04/largest-feathered-dinosaur-discovered-in-china.html |accessdate=4 April 2012}}</ref><ref name=yutyrannus>{{cite journal |author1=Xu, X. |author2=Wang, K. |author3=Zhang, K. |author4=Ma, Q. |author5=Xing, L. |author6=Sullivan, C. |author7=Hu, D. |author8=Cheng, S. |author9=Wang, S. |year=2012 |title=A gigantic feathered dinosaur from the Lower Cretaceous of China |url=http://www.xinglida.net/pdf/Xu_et_al_2012_Yutyrannus.pdf |journal=Nature |volume=484 |issue=7392 |pages=92–95 |doi=10.1038/nature10906 |display-authors=etal |pmid=22481363 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120417134949/http://www.xinglida.net/pdf/Xu_et_al_2012_Yutyrannus.pdf |archivedate=2012-04-17 |df= }}</ref>
==Status in evolutionary biology==
===Reasons for discomfort===
Apparent teleology is a recurring issue in [[evolutionary biology]],<ref>{{cite book |editor1=Ruse, Michael |editor1link=Michael Ruse |editor2=Travis, J. |date=2009 |title=Evolution: The First Four Billion Years |publisher=The Belknap Press of Harvard University Press |page=364}}</ref> much to the consternation of some writers,<ref name="Hanke2004"/> and as an explanatory style it remains controversial.<ref name="Hanke2004">{{cite book |year=2004 |author=Hanke, David |title=Teleology: The explanation that bedevils biology |pages=143–155 |work=Explanations: Styles of explanation in science |editor=Cornwell, John |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=0-19-860778-4 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=ZWpq14vS7WQC&pg=PA143&dq=%22biology+is+sick+%22&q=%22biology%20is%20sick%20%22}}</ref> There are various reasons for discomfort with teleology among biologists.<ref name=Stanford/><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Ribeiro |first1=Manuel Gustavo Leitao|display-authors=etal|title=On the debate about teleology in biology: the notion of "teleological obstacle"|journal=História, Ciências, Saúde-Manguinhos |date=2015 |volume=22 |issue=4 |doi=10.1590/S0104-59702015005000003 |url=http://www.scielo.br/scielo.php?script=sci_arttext&pid=S0104-59702015000401321 |pages=1321–1333}}</ref>
Firstly, the concept of adaptation is itself controversial, as it can be taken to imply, as the evolutionary biologists [[Stephen J. Gould]] and [[Richard Lewontin]] argued, that biologists agree with [[Voltaire]]'s [[Doctor Pangloss]] in his 1759 satire ''[[Candide]]'' that this is "the best of all possible worlds", in other words that every trait is perfectly suited to its functions.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Gould, Stephen J. |author1link=Stephen J. Gould |author2=Lewontin, Richard |author2link=Richard Lewontin |date=1979 |title=The spandrels of San Marco and the Panglossian paradigm: a critique of the adaptationist programme |journal=Proceedings of the Royal Society of London B |issue=205 |pages=581–598 |doi=10.1098/rspb.1979.0086}}</ref> However, all that evolutionary biology requires is the weaker claim that one trait is at least slightly better in a certain context than another, and hence is selected for.<ref name=Stanford/>
[[File:Louis George Meistergraveurin 1.jpg|thumb|The [[Watchmaker analogy]] argues that the presence of a complex mechanism like a watch implies the existence of a conscious designer.]]
Secondly, teleology is linked to the pre-Darwinian idea of [[natural theology]], that the natural world gives evidence of the [[intelligent design|conscious design]] and beneficent intentions of a creator, as in the writings of John Ray.<ref name=Stanford/> [[William Derham]] continued Ray's tradition with books such as his 1713 ''Physico-Theology'' and his 1714 ''Astro-Theology''.<ref>{{cite book |author=Weber, A. S. |title=Nineteenth-Century Science: An Anthology |publisher=Broadview Press |date=2000 |page=18}}</ref> They in turn influenced [[William Paley]] who wrote a detailed [[teleological argument]] for God in 1802, ''[[Natural Theology, or Evidences of the Existence and Attributes of the Deity collected from the Appearances of Nature]]'',<ref>{{cite book |last=Paley |first=William |authorlink=William Paley |title=Natural Theology |date=2006 |origyear=1802 |publisher=Oxford University Press |location=Oxford |url=https://www.academia.edu/1112017/William_Paleys_Natural_Theology_2006_Reprinted_2008_}}</ref> starting with the [[Watchmaker analogy]].<ref>{{cite journal | author=Eddy, Matthew Daniel |title=Nineteenth Century Natural Theology | journal=The Oxford Handbook of Natural Theology | date=2013 | url=https://www.academia.edu/1112017/William_Paleys_Natural_Theology_2006_Reprinted_2008_}}</ref> Such [[creationism]], along with a vitalist life-force and directed orthogenetic evolution, has been rejected by most biologists.<ref name=Stanford/>
Thirdly, attributing purposes to adaptations risks confusion with popular forms of [[Lamarckism]] where animals in particular have been supposed to influence their own evolution through their intentions, though Lamarck himself spoke rather of habits of use, and the belief that his thinking was teleological has been challenged.<ref name=Mayr1992/><ref name="Burkhardt2013">{{cite journal |last1=Burkhardt |first1=Richard W. |title=Lamarck, Evolution, and the Inheritance of Acquired Characters |journal=Genetics |volume=194 |issue=4 |year=2013 |pages=793–805 |doi=10.1534/genetics.113.151852}}</ref><ref name="Bednarczyk 2009 pp. 31–98">{{cite | last=Bednarczyk | first=A | title=[Jean-Baptiste de Lamarck (1744-1829). A dispute on the mechanism of evolution. On the bicentenary of the publication of Philosophie Zoologique (1809)]. | journal=Kwartalnik historii nauki i techniki : Kwartal'nyi zhurnal istorii nauki i tekhniki - | volume=54 | issue=3-4 | year=2009 | issn=0023-589X | pmid=20481104 | language=pl | pages=31–98}}</ref>
Fourthly, the teleological explanation of adaptation is uncomfortable because it seems to require backward causation, in which existing traits are explained by future outcomes; because it seems to attribute the action of a conscious mind when none is assumed to be present in an organism; and because, as a result, adaptation looks impossible to test [[Empirical evidence|empirically]].<ref name=Stanford/>
A fifth reason concerns students rather than researchers: Gonzalez Galli argues that since people naturally imagine that evolution has a purpose or direction, then the use of teleological language by scientists may act as an obstacle to students when [[Teaching evolution|learning about natural selection]]. Such language, he argues, should be removed to make teaching more effective.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Gonzalez Galli |first1=Leonardo Martin |last2=Meinardi |first2=Elsa N. |title=The Role of Teleological Thinking in Learning the Darwinian Model of Evolution |journal=Evolution: Education and Outreach |date=March 2011 |volume=4 |issue=1 |pages=145–152 |doi=10.1007/s12052-010-0272-7}}</ref>
===Removable teleological shorthand===
Statements which imply that nature has goals, for example where a species is said to do something "in order to" achieve survival, appear teleological, and therefore invalid to evolutionary biologists. It is however usually possible to rewrite such sentences to avoid the apparent teleology. Some biology courses have incorporated exercises requiring students to rephrase such sentences so that they do not read teleologically. Nevertheless, biologists still frequently write in a way which can be read as implying teleology, even though that is not their intention.<ref name=Reiss>{{cite book |author=Reiss, John O. |date=2009 |title=Not by Design: Retiring Darwin's Watchmaker |publisher=University of California Press |page= }}</ref> John Reiss argues that evolutionary biology can be purged of apparent teleology by rejecting the pre-Darwinian watchmaker analogy for natural selection;<ref name=Reiss/><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Depew |first1=David J. |title=Is Evolutionary Biology Infected with Invalid Teleological Reasoning? A Review of "Not By Design: Retiring Darwin's Watchmaker" by John O. Reiss |journal=Philosophy in Theory and Biology |date=2010 |volume=2 |issue=20160629 |doi=10.3998/ptb.6959004.0002.005|url=http://quod.lib.umich.edu/p/ptb/6959004.0002.005/--is-evolutionary-biology-infected-with-invalid-teleological?rgn=main;view=fulltext}}</ref> other arguments against this analogy have also been promoted by writers such as the evolutionary biologist [[Richard Dawkins]].<ref>{{cite book |author=Dawkins, Richard |date=1987 |title=The Blind Watchmaker: Why the Evidence of Evolution Reveals a Universe Without Design |publisher=W W Norton |page= }}</ref>
Some philosophers of biology such as [[James G. Lennox]] have argued that Darwin was a teleologist,<ref>{{cite journal |authorlink=James G. Lennox |author=Lennox, James G. |date=1993 |title=Darwin was a Teleologist |journal=Biology and Philosophy |volume=8 |issue=4 |pages=409–421 |doi=10.1007/bf00857687}}</ref> while others like [[Michael Ghiselin]] described this claim as a myth promoted by misinterpretations of his discussions, and emphasized the distinction between using teleological metaphors and actually being teleological.<ref>{{cite journal | doi=10.1007/BF00850377 | last1=Ghiselin | first1=Michael T. | year=1994 | title=Darwin's language may seem teleological, but his thinking is another matter | url=http://www.springerlink.com/content/l1324662n645244w/| journal=Biology and Philosophy | volume=9 | issue=4 | pages=489–492}}</ref> Andrew Askland, from the [[Sandra Day O'Connor College of Law]] claims that unlike [[transhumanism]], an ideology that aims to improve the [[human condition]], which he asserts is "wholly teleological", Darwinian evolution is not teleological.<ref>{{cite journal |url=https://web.law.asu.edu/Portals/31/Askland_transhumanism_IJETS.pdf |author=Askland, Andrew |title=The Misnomer of Transhumanism as Directed Evolution |journal=International Journal of Emerging Technologies and Society |volume=9 |issue=1 |date=2011 |pages=71–78}}</ref>
Various commentators view the teleological phrases used in modern evolutionary biology as a type of [[shorthand]] for describing any function which offers an evolutionary advantage through natural selection. For example, the zoologist S. H. P. Madrell wrote that "the proper but cumbersome way of describing change by evolutionary adaptation [may be] substituted by shorter overtly teleological statements" for the sake of saving space, but that this "should not be taken to imply that evolution proceeds by anything other than from mutations arising by chance, with those that impart an advantage being retained by natural selection."<ref>{{cite journal |author=Madrell, S.H.P. |date=1998 |title=Why are there no insects in the open sea? |journal=The Journal of Experimental Biology |volume=201 |pages=2461–2464}}</ref>
===Irreducible teleology===
Other philosophers of biology argue instead that biological teleology is irreducible, and cannot be removed by any simple process of rewording. [[Francisco J. Ayala|Francisco Ayala]] argued that all statements about processes can be trivially translated into teleological statements, and vice versa, but that teleological statements are more explanatory and cannot be disposed of.<ref name=Ayala1977>{{cite book |author=Ayala, Francisco J. |authorlink=Francisco J. Ayala |date=1977 |title=Teleological explanations |editor=Dobzhansky, T. |editorlink=Theodosius Dobzhansky |work=Evolution |publisher=W.H. Freeman |pages=497–504}}</ref><ref name="Ayala 1998">[[Francisco J. Ayala|Ayala, Francisco]] (1998). "Teleological explanations in evolutionary biology." ''Nature's purposes: Analyses of Function and Design in Biology''. The MIT Press.</ref> Karen Neander similarly argued that the modern concept of [[function (biology)|biological 'function']] depends on [[natural selection]]. So, for example, it is not possible to say that anything that simply winks into existence, without going through a process of selection, actually has functions. We decide whether an [[appendage]] has a function by analysing the process of selection that led to it. Therefore, Neander argues, any talk of functions must be posterior to natural selection, function must be defined by reference to the history of a species, and teleology cannot be avoided.<ref>Neander, Karen (1998). "Functions as Selected Effects: The Conceptual Analyst's Defense," in C. Allen, M. Bekoff & G. Lauder (Eds.), ''Nature's Purposes: Analyses of Function and Design in Biology'' (pp. 313–333). The MIT Press.</ref> The evolutionary biologist [[Ernst Mayr]] likewise stated that "adaptedness ... is an ''[[Empirical evidence|a posteriori]]'' result rather than an ''[[A priori and a posteriori|a priori]]'' goal-seeking."<ref name=Mayr1992>{{cite journal |authorlink=Ernst Mayr |author=Mayr, Ernst W. |date=1992 |title=The idea of teleology |journal=Journal of the History of Ideas |volume=53 |pages=117–135 |doi=10.2307/2709913|jstor=2709913 }}</ref>
Angela Breitenbach, looking at the question of teleology in biology from a [[Immanuel Kant|Kantian]] perspective, argues that teleology is important as "a [[heuristic]] in the search for causal explanations of nature and ... an inevitable [[analogy|analogical]] perspective on living beings." In her view of Kant, teleology implies something that cannot be explained by science, but only understood through analogy.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Breitenbach |first1=Angela |title=Teleology in Biology : A Kantian Perspective |date=2009 |pages=31–56 |url=http://www.phil.cam.ac.uk/people/teaching-research-pages/breitenbach/breitenbach-teleologybiology.pdf |journal=Kant Yearbook |volume=2009 |issue=1}}</ref>
[[Colin Pittendrigh]] coined the similar term '[[teleonomy]]' for apparently goal-directed biological phenomena.<ref name=Pittendrigh>{{cite book |author=Pittendrigh, Colin S. |authorlink=Colin Pittendrigh |title="Adaptation, natural selection, and behavior" |work=Behavior and Evolution |editor1=Roe, A.|editor2=Simpson, George Gaylord |editor2-link=George Gaylord Simpson|location=New Haven |publisher=Yale University Press |date=1958 |pages=390–416}}</ref> [[Ernst Mayr]] criticised Pittendrigh's confusion of Aristotle's [[four causes]], arguing that evolution only involved the material and formal but not the efficient cause.{{efn|Both Pittendrigh and Mayr endorsed teleology in biology as an inherent part of evolutionary thinking.<ref name=Pittendrigh/><ref name=Mayr/>}} Mayr proposed to use the term only for "systems operating on the basis of a program of coded information."<ref name=Mayr>{{cite book |author=Mayr, Ernst |authorlink=Ernst Mayr |chapter=Cause and effect in biology |editor=Lerner, D. |title=Cause and effect |publisher=Free Press |location=New York |date=1965 |pages=33–50}}</ref>
[[William C. Wimsatt]] affirmed that the teleologicality of the language of biology and other fields derives from the logical structure of their background theories, and not merely from the use of teleological locutions such as "function" and "in order to". He stated that "To replace talk about function by talk about selection [...] is not to eliminate teleology but to rephrase it". However, Wimsatt argues that this thought does not mean an appeal to [[backwards causation]], [[vitalism]], [[entelechy]], or [[Antireductionism|anti-reductionist]] sentiments.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Wimsatt, W. |authorlink=William C. Wimsatt |year=1972 |title=Teleology and the logical structure of function statements |journal=Studies in the History and Philosophy of Science |volume=3 |pages=1–80 |url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0039368172900143}}</ref>
The biologist [[J. B. S. Haldane]] observed that "Teleology is like a mistress to a biologist: he cannot live without her but he's unwilling to be seen with her in public."<ref>{{cite book |author=Hull, D. |title=Philosophy of Biological Science |publisher=Prentice-Hall |date=1973 |page=}}</ref><ref>[[Ernst Mayr|Mayr, Ernst]] (1974) Boston Studies in the Philosophy of Science, Volume XIV, pages 91–117.</ref>

{{Infobox book | name = The Postmodern Condition | title_orig = La condition postmoderne: rapport sur le savoir | author = [[Jean-François Lyotard]] | translator = [[Geoffrey Bennington]] and [[Brian Massumi]] | image = File:The Postmodern Condition (French edition).gif | caption = Cover of the French edition | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = France | language = French | series = | subject = Postmodern culture, technology, epistemology | published = {{plainlist| *1979 ([[Les Éditions de Minuit]]) *1984 (University of Minnesota Press, in English) }} | media_type = Print | pages = | isbn = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''The Postmodern Condition: A Report on Knowledge''''' ({{lang-fr|La condition postmoderne: rapport sur le savoir}}) is a 1979 book by [[Jean-François Lyotard]], in which Lyotard analyzes the [[epistemology|notion of knowledge]] in [[postmodernity|postmodern]] society as the end of 'grand narratives' or [[metanarrative]]s, which he considers a quintessential feature of [[modernity]]. Lyotard introduced the term 'postmodernism', which was previously only used by art critics, into philosophy and social sciences, with the following observation: "Simplifying to the extreme, I define postmodern as incredulity towards metanarratives".<ref name="Lyotard">Lyotard, Jean-François (1979). ''La condition postmoderne: rapport sur le savoir''. Paris: Minuit.</ref><ref name="Anderson">[[Perry Anderson|Anderson, Perry]] (1998). ''The Origins of Postmodernity''. London/New York: Verso, pp. 24–27.</ref><ref>Quotation from the 1984 (reprint 1997); English translation by [[Geoffrey Bennington]] and [[Brian Massumi]], University of Minnesota Press.</ref> Originally written as a report on the influence of technology in [[exact science]]s, commissioned by the ''Conseil des universités du [[Québec]]'', ''The Postmodern Condition'' was influential.<ref name="Bruneault">Bruneault, Frédérick (Autumn 2004). "[https://www.ulaval.ca/phares/vol5-automne04/texte03.html Savoir scientifique et légitimation]", ''Revue PHARES'' vol. '''5'''.</ref><ref>Lyotard, Jean-Francois (1979). [http://www.cse.gouv.qc.ca/fichiers/documents/publications/ConseilUniversite/Problemes_savoir_soc_indus_develop-1980.pdf "Les problèmes du savoir dans les sociétés industrielles les plus développées"]. Quebec: Conseil des Universités. Original report available online at: http://www.cse.gouv.qc.ca/FR/Publications_CUniv/</ref> Lyotard later admitted that he had a "less than limited" knowledge of the science he was to write about, deeming ''The Postmodern Condition'' his worst book.
==Summary== Lyotard criticizes metanarratives such as [[reductionism]] and [[teleology|teleological]] notions of human history such as those of the [[Age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment]] and [[Marxism]], arguing that they have become untenable because of [[technology|technological]] progress in the areas of [[communication]], [[mass media]] and [[computer science]]. Techniques such as [[artificial intelligence]] and [[machine translation]] show a shift to [[language|linguistic]] and symbolic production as central elements of the [[postindustrial]] economy and the related postmodern culture, which had risen at the end of the 1950s after the reconstruction of [[western Europe]]. The result is a plurality of [[language-game]]s (a term coined by [[Ludwig Wittgenstein]]<ref name="Lyotard"/>{{rp|67}}), of different types of argument. At the same time, the goal of truth in science is replaced by "performativity" and efficiency in the service of capital or the state, and science produces paradoxical results such as [[chaos theory]], all of which undermine science's grand narrative.<ref name="Anderson"/> Lyotard professes a preference for this plurality of small narratives that compete with each other, replacing the [[totalitarianism]] of grand narratives.
==Reception== ''The Postmodern Condition'' was influential.<ref name="Bruneault" /> However, Lyotard later admitted that he had a "less than limited" knowledge of the [[science]] he wrote about, and to compensate for this knowledge, he "made stories up" and referred to a number of books that he hadn't actually read. In retrospect, he called it "a [[parody]]" and "simply the worst of all my books".<ref name="Anderson"/> Poet [[Frederick Turner (poet)|Frederick Turner]] writes that, like many post-structuralist works, ''The Postmodern Condition'' "has not worn well." However, he sees it more readable than other post-structuralist works, and credits Lyotard with covering "a good deal of ground in a lively and economical fashion."<ref>Turner, Frederick. ''The Culture of Hope: A New Birth of the Classical Spirit''. The Free Press, 1995, p. 283.</ref>
==See also== * ''[[The Differend]]''
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Postmodern Condition, The}} [[Category:1979 books]] [[Category:Books by Jean-François Lyotard]] [[Category:Contemporary philosophical literature]] [[Category:Epistemology literature]] [[Category:Philosophy books]] [[Category:Works about postmodernism]]

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/Lovemankind83|Lovemankind83]] ([[User talk:Lovemankind83|talk]]) to last version by InternetArchiveBot
revision.text:
"'''Vast right-wing conspiracy'''" is a [[conspiracy theory]] popularized by a 1995 memo by political opposition researcher [[Chris Lehane]] and then referenced in 1998 by the then [[First Lady of the United States]] [[Hillary Clinton]], in defense of her husband, President [[Bill Clinton]], characterizing the continued allegations of scandal against her and her husband, including the [[Lewinsky scandal]], as part of a long campaign by Clinton's political enemies.{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/politics/special/clinton/stories/hillary012898.htm |title=First Lady Launches Counterattack |newspaper=[[Washington Post]] |accessdate=2009-06-14}} The term has been used since, including in a question posed to Bill Clinton in 2009 to describe verbal attacks on [[Barack Obama]] during [[Presidency of Barack Obama|his early presidency]]. Hillary Clinton mentioned it again during her [[Hillary Clinton presidential campaign, 2016|2016 presidential campaign]]. ==Earlier uses== While popularized by Mrs. Clinton in her 1998 TODAY Show interview,{{cite news|last1=Lauer|first1=Matt|title=Hillary Clinton speaks out on Lewinsky accusations|url=http://www.msnbc.com/today/watch/hillary-clinton-speaks-out-on-lewinsky-accusations-44498499720|accessdate=26 March 2017|agency=NBC News|publisher=TODAY Show|date=27 January 1998|format=Video}}{{cite news|last1=Maraniss|first1=David|title=First Lady Launches Counterattack|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/politics/special/clinton/stories/hillary012898.htm|accessdate=26 March 2017|publisher=The Washington Post|date=28 January 1998|pages=A01}} the phrase did not originate with her. In 1991 the ''[[Detroit News]]'' wrote: {{quote|Thatcher-era Britain produced its own crop of paranoid left-liberal films. ... ''All posited a vast right-wing conspiracy'' propping up a reactionary government ruthlessly crushing all efforts at opposition under the guise of parliamentary democracy. [Emphasis added.]cited in Wayne Glawka, et al., "Among the New Words," ''American Speech'' 75 (2000): 430– 46, at p. 444}} An ''[[Associated Press]]'' story in 1995 also used the phrase, relating an official's guess that the [[Oklahoma City bombing]] was the work of "maybe five malcontents" and not "some kind of vast right-wing conspiracy."{{sfn|Safire|2008}} ==1995 memo== A 332-page memo titled "Communication Stream of Conspiracy Commerce" was commissioned by [[Mark Fabiani]] and written by [[Chris Lehane]] in 1995. It was the first document to describe the conspiracies surrounding the Clintons, which Hillary Clinton later popularized with the term "vast right-wing conspiracy."{{cite web |last=Garofoli |first=Joe |url=http://www.sfgate.com/politics/joegarofoli/article/The-Spinner-How-Chris-Lehane-revered-by-some-2679295.php |title=The Spinner / How Chris Lehane, revered by some and reviled by others, gets the campaign consultant job done |date=October 24, 2004 |work=SFGate |accessdate=January 11, 2017}} It described how online conservative media outlets such as ''[[The American Spectator]]'' spread conspiracy theories about the [[suicide of Vince Foster]], the [[Whitewater controversy]], and other events. According to the memo, these conspiracies spread from conservative think tanks to British tabloids, and then to the mainstream press.{{cite web |last=Good |first=Chris |url=http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/politics/2014/04/clinton-white-houses-conspiracy-theory-of-right-wing-conspiracy-theories/ |title=Clinton White House's Conspiracy Theory of Right-Wing Conspiracy Theories |date=April 18, 2014 |work=ABC News |accessdate=January 11, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170113090638/http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/politics/2014/04/clinton-white-houses-conspiracy-theory-of-right-wing-conspiracy-theories/ |archive-date=2017-01-13 |dead-url=yes |df= }} ==''The Today Show'' interview== {{refimprove section|date=August 2016}} In response to ongoing accusations surrounding the Clintons' investment in a real estate development known as [[Whitewater controversy|Whitewater]] in the late 1970s and early 1980s, Clinton's [[Attorney General of the United States|Attorney General]] [[Janet Reno]] had appointed an [[independent counsel]], [[Kenneth Starr]], to investigate those accusations in 1994. Starr's investigation began to branch out into other issues, from [[Filegate]] to [[Travelgate]] to Bill Clinton's actions in the civil case of his alleged sexual harassment of [[Paula Jones]] prior to his presidency. In the course of the last of these, [[White House]] intern [[Monica Lewinsky]] signed an affidavit that she had not had a relationship with Clinton, but Lewinsky's confidant [[Linda Tripp]] had been recording their phone conversations and offered Starr tapes of Lewinsky describing her feelings for, and alleging intimate encounters with, the president. The president was asked to give a deposition, and accusations that he lied about an affair under oath first made national headlines on January 17, 1998, when the story was picked up by the conservative-right e-mail newsletter ''[[The Drudge Report]]''. Despite swift denials from President Clinton, the media attention grew. On January 27, 1998, Hillary Clinton appeared on [[NBC]]'s ''[[Today (NBC program)|The Today Show]]'', in an interview with [[Matt Lauer]]. {{quote|'''Matt Lauer''': You have said, I understand, to some close friends, that this is the last great battle, and that one side or the other is going down here. '''Hillary Clinton''': Well, I don't know if I've been that dramatic. That would sound like a good line from a movie. But I do believe that this is a battle. I mean, look at the very people who are involved in this—they have popped up in other settings. This is—the great story here for anybody willing to find it and write about it and explain it is this vast right-wing conspiracy that has been conspiring against my husband since the day he announced for president.}} Clinton elaborated by decrying the tactics "and the kind of intense political agenda at work here". [[Bob Woodward]] recounts in his book ''The Agenda'' (1994) that the then-first lady claimed that when her husband was making his decision to run for the presidency in 1991, he reported receiving "a direct threat from someone in the Bush White House, warning that if he ran, the Republicans would go after him. 'We will do everything we can to destroy you personally,' she recalled that the Bush White House man had said." ==Later uses== [[David Brock]], a conservative-turned-liberal author, has said he was once a part of an effort to dredge up a scandal against Clinton.{{cite news | url=http://www.cnn.com/ALLPOLITICS/1998/03/10/brocks.remorse/ | title=Reporter Apologizes For Clinton Sex Article | publisher=[[CNN]] |date= March 10, 1998 | first= | last= | accessdate =2008-10-17 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080614124146/http://www.cnn.com/ALLPOLITICS/1998/03/10/brocks.remorse/ |archivedate = June 14, 2008}} In 1993 Brock, then of the ''[[American Spectator]]'', was the first to report Paula Jones' claims. As Brock explained in ''[[Blinded by the Right]]'', after learning more about the events and conservative payments surrounding [[Paula Jones]] he personally apologized to the Clintons. He documented his experience in ''[[Blinded by the Right|Blinded by the Right: The Conscience of an Ex-Conservative]]'', wherein he alleged that Arkansas state troopers had taken money in exchange for testimony against Clinton which Brock had published in a previous book. [[Adam Curtis]] also discusses the concept in his documentary series ''[[The Power of Nightmares]]''. Brock has agreed with Clinton's claim that there was a "Right wing conspiracy" to smear her husband, quibbling only with the characterization of it as "vast", since Brock contends that it was orchestrated mainly by a few powerful people. [[MSNBC]] also described the comment as once-ridiculed but now taken more seriously by "many Democrats" who point "to the well-documented efforts by conservative financier Richard Mellon Scaife to fund a network of anti-Clinton investigations."{{cite news |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/17593375/ns/politics-decision_08/t/clinton-vast-right-wing-conspiracy-back/ |title=Clinton: Vast right-wing conspiracy is back |publisher=MSNBC |agency=Associated Press |date=March 13, 2007}} Specific claims of such funding have been made against conservative Republican supporter and billionaire [[Richard Mellon Scaife]].Media Transparency, [http://www.mediatransparency.org/scaifeaggregate.php Aggregated Grants from the Scaife Foundations.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070608130352/http://www.mediatransparency.org/scaifeaggregate.php |date=2007-06-08 }} Scaife played a major role in funding the [[Arkansas Project]] investigating President Clinton; former Clinton [[White House Counsel]] [[Lanny Davis]] claimed Scaife was using his money "to destroy a president of the United States." Scaife claims to be public about his political spending (q.v.{{cite web|url=http://www.scaife.org|title=scaife.org|publisher=}}). CNN stated in a study the news outlet conducted on Scaife, "If it's a conspiracy, it's a pretty open one."{{cite news| url=http://www.cnn.com/ALLPOLITICS/1998/04/27/scaife.profile/ | work=CNN | accessdate=May 27, 2010 | title=Who Is Richard Mellon Scaife? | first=Brooks | last=Jackson}} Hillary Clinton wrote in her 2003 autobiography, "Looking back, I see that I might have phrased my point more artfully, but I stand by the characterization of Starr's investigation [regardless of the truth about Lewinsky]."''Living History'', p. 446. By 2007 her experiences caused Hillary Clinton to say in presidential campaign appearances that the vast right-wing conspiracy was back, citing such cases as the [[2002 New Hampshire Senate election phone jamming scandal]].[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/17593375/ Clinton: Vast right-wing conspiracy is back], MSNBC/AP, March 13, 2007 On the [[Stump speech (politics)|stump]] for [[Al Franken]]'s 2008 Senate campaign, Bill Clinton acknowledged his [[Air America Radio]] show by quipping that he had been taking on the "vast right wing conspiracy before others even acknowledged that it existed".{{cite web|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/the-trail/2008/10/21/hillary_clinton_al_franken_and.html|title=Hillary Clinton, Al Franken and the Return of the Vast Right-Wing Conspiracy|publisher=[[The Washington Post]]|date=October 21, 2008|author=Kane, Paul}} Former President Clinton, when asked on ''[[Meet the Press]]'' (September 27, 2009) whether the vast right wing conspiracy was involved in the attacks on President [[Barack Obama]], said "Oh, you bet. Sure it is. It's not as strong as it was, because America's changed demographically, but it's as virulent as it was ... when they accused me of murder and all that stuff."Meet the Press, 21 Sept. 2009, [http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/33032390/ns/meet_the_press/page/2/ transcript] Two other figures who have used the phrase are Nobel laureate economist [[Paul Krugman]] and journalist [[Joe Conason]]. Conason, in an article called "The vast right-wing conspiracy is back," refers the [[National Republican Trust PAC]] and [[Newsmax Media]], which are run by former foes of Bill Clinton and who made attacks on then-President Barack Obama. The National Republican Trust PAC sponsored a campaign commercials against Obama in 2008 which [[FactCheck.org]] described as "one of the sleaziest false TV ads of the campaign." One of Newsmax Media's owners "was among the most insistent endorsers of the [[Barack Obama citizenship conspiracy theories|Obama birth certificate myth]]" and a popularizer of the canard that Bill Clinton's White House counsel [[Suicide of Vince Foster|Vince Foster]] did not commit suicide—as determined by five official investigations—but was murdered.[http://www.salon.com/2009/10/05/clinton_obama_17/ The vast right-wing conspiracy is back]. Salon.com Oct 5, 2009 In some of his books, Krugman has used the phrase ("Yes, Virginia, there is a vast right-wing conspiracy"{{sfn|Krugman|2004|pages=217, 269–71}}) to refer not to a conservative Republican-leaning campaign against Clinton (or Obama), but more generally to "an interlocking set of institutions ultimately answering to a small group of people that collectively reward loyalists and punish dissenters" in the service of "[[movement conservatism]]." The network of institutions provide
obedient politicians with the resources to win elections, safe havens in the event of defeat, and lucrative career opportunities after they leave office. They guarantee favorable news coverage to politicians who follow the party line, while harassing and undermining opponents. And they support a large standing army of party intellectuals and activists.{{sfn|Krugman|2007|page=163}}
In Krugman's view, the network of foundations that fund conservative scholarship, the national and regional think tanks and advocacy groups, talk radio media outlets, and conservative law firms through which they pushed their agenda to move the Republican Party to the right, far surpass in funding, size, inter-connectedness or influence anything the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] or the American liberal movement have at their disposal. ==2014 reemergence== In April 2014, the [[Clinton Presidential Center]] published the original 1995 memo on the conspiracy. The memo's author, Chris Lehane, wrote, "As for the premise of the memo, I absolutely stand by it. Not only was it right about the right wing then, it is more accurate than ever today."{{cite web |last=Lehane |first=Chris |url=http://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2014/04/chris-lehane-right-wing-conspiracy-memo-106059 |title=Yeah, I Wrote the Vast Right-Wing Conspiracy Memo |date=April 27, 2014 |work=POLITICO Magazine |accessdate=January 11, 2017}} ==2016 reemergence== In 2016, Hillary Clinton said she still believed in the "vast right-wing conspiracy", adding that it was "even better funded" 18 years later.{{cite news|last1=Condon|first1=Stephanie|title=Hillary Clinton: The vast, right-wing conspiracy" is "even better funded" now|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/hillary-clinton-the-vast-right-wing-conspiracy-is-even-better-funded-now/|accessdate=February 5, 2016|work=CBS News|date=February 3, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Chance|first1=Seales|title=Hillary Clinton's affinity for conspiracy theories|url=http://wiat.com/2016/08/14/hillarys-clintons-affinity-for-conspiracy-theories/|website=[[WIAT]].com|publisher=[[LIN Media|LIN Television Corp.]] ([[Media General]])|location=[[Birmingham, AL]]|date=August 14, 2016|quote=... Clinton holds an affinity for conspiracy theories little known to the American public.}} However, she opined, "At this point it's probably not correct to say it's a conspiracy because it's out in the open." In October, after [[Donald Trump and Billy Bush recording|footage]] of [[Donald Trump]] boasting about his sexual exploits emerged and [[Donald Trump sexual misconduct allegations|multiple women accused Trump of sexual misconduct]], [[Melania Trump]] defended her husband and said, "This was all organized from the opposition."{{cite web |last=Mehta |first=Seema |url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/politics/trailguide/la-na-trailguide-updates-melania-trump-echoes-hillary-clinton-as-1476823147-htmlstory.html |title=Melania Trump echoes Hillary Clinton as she defends her husband |date=October 18, 2016 |work=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=January 8, 2017}} Writers for the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' and ''[[The Washington Post]]'' noted that Melania's response "echoed" Hillary's original use of the phrase "vast right-wing conspiracy."{{cite web |last=Tumulty |first=Karen |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/melania-trump-takes-a-page-from-hillary-clintons-playbook-clean-up/2016/10/18/7c0420b2-9520-11e6-bc79-af1cd3d2984b_story.html |title=Melania Trump takes a page from Hillary Clinton's playbook |date=October 18, 2016 |work=Washington Post |accessdate=January 8, 2017}} ==Use in popular culture== After the release of a deposition Bill Clinton had given to [[Starr Report|the Independent Counsel]] in which he [[perjury|perjured]] himself, some conservatives began to adopt the VRWC phrasing ironically. In 2004, conservative lawyer [[Mark W. Smith]] wrote the [[New York Times Best Seller list|''New York Times'' Best Seller]] ''[[Official Handbook of the Vast Right-Wing Conspiracy]]'', which came with a "membership card" that made its owner an "official member of the VRWC." Similarly, a number of newspaper, magazine, and website articles have used the phrase to report on [[left-wing politics]].{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/07/25/magazine/25DEMOCRATS.html |title=Wiring the Vast Left-Wing Conspiracy |work=[[The New York Times Magazine]] |date=2004-07-25 |first=Matt |last=Bai |publisher=[[New York Times]] |accessdate=May 27, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100407220527/http://www.nytimes.com/2004/07/25/magazine/25DEMOCRATS.html |archivedate=April 7, 2010 |df= }}{{cite web | url=http://webm.powerparcel.com/domains/domainsponsor_all.php?parent=dsflip_live&domain=joinspencer.com | title=The Clinton-McFarland Connection: A vast left-wing conspiracy? | access-date=2007-04-28 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070504020428/http://webm.powerparcel.com/domains/domainsponsor_all.php?parent=dsflip_live&domain=joinspencer.com# | archive-date=2007-05-04 | dead-url=yes | df= }} [[Eugene Volokh]]'s blog [[The Volokh Conspiracy]] is said to have derived its name from as a reference to the "Vast right-wing conspiracy" statement.{{Cite news|url=http://www.tabletmag.com/jewish-news-and-politics/168389/the-volokh-conspiracy|title=The Volokh Conspiracy Is Out To Get You|newspaper=Tablet Magazine|access-date=2017-02-07|language=en}} The term "Vast Right Wing Conspiracy" continues to be mocked by conservatives.{{cite news |title= Another Vast Right Wing Conspiracy |publisher=[[Wall Street Journal]] |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703439504576116192584262296#articleTabs%3Darticle |date=January 31, 2011 |first=Collin |last=Levy}}{{cite news |title= Another "Vast Right Wing Conspiracy," Hillary? |publisher=[[Canada Free Press]] |url=http://canadafreepress.com/index.php/article/55085 |date=May 9, 2013 |first=John |last=Lillpop}} ==See also== *[[Clinton crazies]] ==References== ===Notes=== {{Reflist|30em}} ===Sources=== *{{cite book |last1=Krugman |first1=Paul R. |title=The Great Unraveling: Losing Our Way in the New Century |publisher=[[W. W. Norton & Company]] |year=2004 |pages=217, 269–71 |isbn=0-393-32605-5 |ref=harv}} *{{cite book |last1=Krugman |first1=Paul R. |title=The Conscience of a Liberal|publisher=W. W. Norton & Company |year=2007 |page=163 |isbn=978-0-393-06069-0 |ref=harv}} *{{cite book |last1=Safire |first1=William |authorlink1=William Safire |title=Safire's Political Dictionary |location=New York |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |year=2008 |edition=Revised |isbn=978-0195340617 |ref=harv}} ==Further reading== *{{Cite book | last = Bellant | first = Russ |authorlink=Russ Bellant | title =The Coors Connection: How Coors Philanthropy Undermines Democratic Pluralism |location=Boston, Massachusetts | year = 1991|publisher=South End Press |isbn=0896084175 }} *{{cite book|last1=Conason |first1=Joe |author1-link=Joe Conason |last2=Lyons |first2=Gene |author2-link=Gene Lyons|title=The hunting of the President: the ten-year campaign to destroy Bill and Hillary Clinton|year=2000|publisher=Thomas Dunne Books|location=New York|isbn=0-312-27319-3}} *{{cite journal |url=http://www.emeraldinsight.com/doi/abs/10.1108/00907329910260444 |work=[[Reference Services Review]] |title=Right-wing opposition to Bill Clinton and his presidency: an annotated bibliography |doi=10.1108/00907329910260444 |issn=0090-7324 |first1=Allan |last1=Metz |year=1999 |volume=27 |issue=1 |pages=13–61}}{{subscription}} ==External links== *[http://leany.com/Conspiracy/hillary_clinton_transcript.htm Transcript of Hillary Clinton interview] on [[NBC Today Show]] *[http://mediamattersaction.org/transparency/ Who's funding the Conservative Movement?] ;Media coverage *[http://www.today.com/video/hillary-clinton-speaks-out-on-lewinsky-accusations-44498499720 Video: Hillary Clinton Speaks Out on Lewinsky Allegations] via ''[[NBC Today Show]]'', January 27, 1998 *[http://www.cnn.com/ALLPOLITICS/1998/01/27/hillary.today/ Hillary Clinton: 'This Is A Battle'], ''[[CNN]]'', January 27, 1998 *[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/politics/special/clinton/stories/hillary012898.htm Washington Post: First Lady Launches Counterattack], ''[[The Washington Post]]'', January 28, 1998 *[http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/1998/05/19/archive/main9813.shtml Caught In The Whitewater Net], ''[[CBS News]]'', May 19, 1998 *[http://www.corporations.org/coors/article.html It's no accident that Coors is the right beer in America], undated *[https://www.forbes.com/sites/rickungar/2011/03/21/the-vast-right-wing-conspiracy-2011-less-vast-more-powerful/ The Vast Right-Wing Conspiracy 2011: Less Vast- More Powerful], Rick Ungar, ''[[Forbes]]'', March 21, 2011 *[http://www.seconnecticut.com/media.htm Why Not Occupy Newsrooms?], October 24, 2011 {{Conspiracy theories}} {{Hillary Rodham Clinton}} {{Portal bar|Politics|United States}} [[Category:American political catchphrases]] [[Category:Conspiracy theories by subject]] [[Category:Conspiracy theories in the United States]] [[Category:English phrases]] [[Category:Hillary Clinton]] [[Category:Clinton–Lewinsky scandal]] [[Category:Political terminology of the United States]] [[Category:Reclaimed words]] [[Category:Right-wing politics]]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Works about philosophy of mathematics]]; added [[Category:Philosophy of mathematics literature]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox book | name = What is Philosophy? | title_orig = Qu'est-ce que la philosophie? | translators = [[Hugh Tomlinson]]
Graham Burchell | image = File:What is Philosophy (French edition).jpg | caption = Cover of the first edition | authors = [[Gilles Deleuze]]
[[Félix Guattari]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = France | language = French | series = | subjects = [[Philosophy of science]]
[[Philosophy of mathematics]] | published ={{plainlist| *1991 (Les éditions de Minuit, in French) *1994 (Columbia University Press, in English) }} | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover]] and [[Paperback]]) | pages = 256 (1996 Columbia University Press edition) | isbn = 978-0231079891 | dewey= | congress= | oclc= | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''What is Philosophy?''''' ({{lang-fr|Qu'est-ce que la philosophie?}}) is a 1991 book by French authors [[Gilles Deleuze]] and [[Félix Guattari]], respectively a philosopher and a psychoanalyst. ==Background== Deleuze commented in a letter to one of his translators that his purpose in writing ''What is Philosophy?'' was to address "the problem of absolute immanence" and to explain why he considered [[Baruch Spinoza]] the "prince of philosophers."{{sfn|Deleuze|1990|page=11}} ==Summary== {{cleanup section||reason=Section is currently based on a secondary source discussing the work. It should be based principally on the book itself|date=June 2018}} [[Deleuze and Guattari]] deal with the distinction between [[philosophy]] and [[science]], arguing that the former deals with concepts and the latter with functions. They discuss the [[philosophy of science]] and the [[philosophy of mathematics]].{{sfn|Sokal|Bricmont|1999|pages=155–159}} ==Reception== The physicists [[Alan Sokal]] and [[Jean Bricmont]], writing in ''[[Fashionable Nonsense]]'' (1997), state that ''What is Philosophy'' became a best-seller in France in 1991. They argue that in attempting to show how philosophy and science are distinct, Deleuze and Guattari use scientific terms such as "[[Chaos theory|chaos]]" in incorrect or misleading ways, and that while in some passages they seem to discuss serious problems in the philosophy of science and mathematics, these passages prove to be largely meaningless on close inspection.{{sfn|Sokal|Bricmont|1999|pages=155–159}} The philosopher [[Roger Scruton]], writing in ''Fools, Frauds and Firebrands: Thinkers of the New Left'' (2016), criticized ''What is Philosophy?'', describing it as poorly written.{{sfn|Scruton|2016|pages=192–193}} ==See also== *[[Immanence]] *[[Metaphilosophy]] ==References== ===Footnotes=== {{reflist|20em}} ===Bibliography=== ;Books {{refbegin}} * {{cite book |last1=Deleuze|first1=Gilles |last2=Joughin|first2=Martin |title=Expressionism in Philosophy: Spinoza |publisher=Zone Books |location=New York |year=1990 |isbn=0-942299-51-5 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate= |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last1=Scruton|first1=Roger |title=Fools, Frauds and Firebrands: Thinkers of the New Left |publisher=[[Bloomsbury Publishing]] |location=London |year=2016 |isbn=978-1-4729-3595-3 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate= |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last1=Sokal|first1=Alan |last2=Bricmont|first2=Jean |title=Fashionable Nonsense: Postmodern Intellectuals' Abuse of Science |publisher=[[Picador (imprint)|Picador]] |location=New York |year=1999 |isbn=0-312-20407-8 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate= |ref=harv}} {{refend}} {{Deleuze-Guattari}} [[Category:1991 books]] [[Category:Books about metaphilosophy]] [[Category:Philosophy of science literature]] [[Category:Philosophy of mathematics literature]] [[Category:Works by Félix Guattari]] [[Category:Works by Gilles Deleuze]]
